{"step_by_step_thinking": "The tetanizing frequency for a muscle is the frequency at which individual twitches overlap and result in a sustained contraction, also known as tetanus. The frequency at which this occurs depends on the duration of the twitch, which includes the latent period, contraction time, and relaxation time. In this case, the total duration of the twitch is 10 ms (latent period) + 40 ms (contraction time) + 50 ms (relaxation time) = 100 ms. The frequency is the reciprocal of the period, so the tetanizing frequency would be 1 / 0.1 s = 10 Hz. However, none of the provided options match this calculation. It's possible that the question assumes that tetanus begins when the twitches start to overlap, which typically happens when the stimulation frequency is higher than the reciprocal of the contraction time plus the relaxation time. In this case, the relevant duration would be 40 ms (contraction time) + 50 ms (relaxation time) = 90 ms, and the corresponding frequency would be 1 / 0.09 s = approximately 11 Hz.
